webTitle: The boom is dead. Long live the boom?

fields.standfirst: The first stage of the mining boom is over. For the second stage to kick in, we need manufacturing to fill a gap
fields.body:
Wednesday's GDP figures, depending on your point of view, are either the first of the post-mining boom economy, or the last gasp of the joy we have felt since 2002 from digging stuff out of the ground.

The mining sector deservedly gets a fair bit of attention. It is, shall we say, a pretty important part of our economy. It constitutes the largest non-services sector of our economy. In gross value added terms it contributes around 10% of our GDP – back in 2000 it contributed only around 5%. Now 10% doesn’t seem like much, but in terms of contributing to growth of our economy, with the financial and insurance services sector, it is the best performer over the past 10 years.

GDP figures released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics showed our economy grew by 2.6% for the past 12 months, down on 3.1% in 2012. Mining’s contribution to the growth was 0.8 percentage points – the biggest of any sector. But the biggest contributor to the growth in this past quarter was net exports – and in the past 12 months we have seen growth in the exports of iron ore and other metals increasing by 18%.

So what’s all this about the end of the mining boom?

When people talk about the mining boom, they are actually talking about the end of the investment in mining. For this we look at the New Capital Expenditure figures, or “capex”. Capex is essentially all the machines and infrastructure needed to make things. It includes construction site development, roads, bridges, wharfs and pipelines. It includes the construction of shafts in underground mines and the preparation of mining and quarrying sites.

If capex is growing, then companies are investing more in the economy in the hopes of (in the case of mining) digging for fairly valuable rocks and selling them.

And when it comes to mining, from 2002–2012 the capex rather boomed, but the figures released by the ABS last Thursday showed clear signs that it has peaked:

To add to this bleak picture, on Monday the ABS released yet more data which showed that the total metres drilled in mining exploration had fallen about 32% in the past year.

So where does this leave us?

Is Australia stuffed?

Well possibly – if we were hoping the investment side of the boom would continue forever. But no one really did. Last October, the head of the Treasury, Martin Parkinson described it as a boom of two stages – the first is the investment side, which came off the back of a boom in prices for our exports. This “terms of trade” boom is now declining – though it remains high compared with the past. The second part of the boom is the extraction of the minerals and their export.

And here we see that the exports of metal ores and minerals is as high as ever and has actually increased in the past three years at a quicker pace than it did in the early stage of the mining boom.

So all good then, yes?

Well, maybe.

The problem is all that capital expenditure involves spending a lot more money than does extraction and exporting, and it also employs a lot more people, so there’s likely to be a drop in the sector's employment.

The glass half full picture, however, is that those workers in the mines can come back to manufacturing and non-mining areas.

But that requires there to be a demand for jobs in those industries. The hope is that the decline in prices for iron ore and other minerals will see the value of our dollar go down, and that will make life easier for our manufacturers who are trying to export their products. But the dollar at US 95 cents is still not low enough for that to happen.

This is where we look at the picture of capital expenditure in the manufacturing sector – it is also falling, and has been since 2010. This is mostly due to the high dollar – but how long can businesses wait for when (or if) the dollar finally falls?

The GDP figures showed us a first look at life as we depend more on export growth than investment growth in the mining sector.

And while the mining sector continues to assist the growth of the economy, it’s worth nothing that in the March quarter, both manufacturing and construction were a drag on economic growth.

If that doesn’t change, things will get a lot tougher for us.
